text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Bulgaria's July monthly inflation rose to 3.7 percent from 0.8 percent in June, the National Statistics Institute said.
-- The Bulgarian National Bank's (BNB) Issue Department foreign exchange assets rose to 3.529 billion marks on August 8 from 3.487 billion marks a week earlier, the BNB said. @
-- Bulgaria's cabinet waived customs fees on imports of 3,000 tonnes of cheese and 250 tonnes of eggs in a bid to cover a consumption gap in the country, Trade Minister Valentin Vassilev said.
-- Bulgaria's central government budget deficit rose by 175 billion levs in the second half of July to 605 billion levs or 64.6 percent of the annual target, Finance ministry officials said.

-- Around 64 percent of Bulgarians say the structural reform in the country should continue regardless of the social cost but 55 percent say they were not familiar with the nature of the econimic reforms, a poll by the National Centre for Studying Public Oppinion showed.
-- Bulgaria's cabinet is expected to introduce a minimum purchase price of 190,000 levs for low quality wheat from this year's crop, Agriculture minister Ventsislav Varbanov said.
The minimum purchase price for first quality bread wheat is set at 230,000 levs. @

-- Bulgaria's Constitutional Court postponed ruling on an appeal by 52 opposition deputies against the bill to open secret police files from the communist era, which was approved by parliament last month.
-- Bulgaria's domestic debt rose to 3.9 trillion levs at end-July from 3.79 a month earlier, central bank figures showed. -- Sofia Newsroom, (++359-2) 981 4145
